bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to [s.n.] Bolduan, April 28, 1919

div1.p: Carter writes to Bolduan about his health. Carter offers his opinions on the genesis of yellow fever in the Americas.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to [s.n.] Bolduan, April 28, 1919

opener.dateline:
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
United States
Public Health Service
U. S. Marine Hospital
New Orleans, La.
April 28, 1919.

div1.p:
I am too sick to write only would say that evidence is rather
strong against malaria existing in the Carribean littoral or Mexico when the whites
arrived. The two expeditions of Raleigh in “Guama, one lasting about 18 months as I
recollect it, were characterized “by neither fever nor calenture.” Both were on the
Orinoco - up which an expedition of some hundreds of whites would yield many deaths
now. The same was true of Quesada's expedition - I do not remember whether it twas
two to fouror one years - from Santa Marta up the Magdalenea to Bogotá. Orellana found none
coming down the Amazon. There was no malaria in John oxenham's expedition across
Darien, nor in Drakes' first expedition until he visited & other places on the Coast Nombre, after which “fevers,
calenture and flux decimated his men. Hawkins' first expeditions to Santo Domingo,
San Juan de'ulloa, and Campeche, were free from sickness, but in all the subsequent
expeditions, passing first by the slave coast of Africa, sickness was a prominent
feature.

I have no books and I am not even strong enough to think but to me
the evidence is strong of malaria not being indigenous in the parts of America first
visited by Spanish and English navigators but since introduced from Africa, Spain, and
no doubt England itself. The Pestilantials of Jamestown, Va., seems to have been a
mixture of dysentery and malaria and probably typhoid. “La Peste Grande” old Herrera
describes in Isabela. His description was one haldf of exalted imagination, having been
reading about Purgatory, and the balance about equal parts scuryy, , malar-
ia, dysentery and syphilis, with probably a fair amount of lying thrown in.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed) H. R. Carter
Assistant Surgeon General. Over
PS- I think the balance of evidence is---with some other ills---we owe malaria
to Africa, in fact I cannot help thinking some of the wavy lines in the Egyptian
hieroglyphics-the significance of which learned men have disputed -were when
the Scribes were trying to draw a straight line while having a chill.
